ratings.comment: Professor Smith is amazing. She is great lecturer and is immensely knowledgeable. She is always keen to answer any questions you may have. However, I do have to say that if you are not interested in math then I would suggest another professor. Her class is very conceptual and more theoretical than the other sections.

This professor was the worst professor I have ever had. I have never written one of these before, but this was so bad it made me. When I say the material is not very difficult, but she finds a way to make the tests impossible mean it. Zero emphasis on stuff that matters and all emphasis on weird exclusion cases using variables and not numbers.

Leslie Smith teaches math 320 as if it is a graduate class. Her lectures are ok, and the homework isn't wild. However the exams are wildly disproportionately more difficult than the other sections. Other sections midterm ave sat at 85 to 90, Leslie's midterms had 60% averages. Good for challenge, but if you're not a math major, not worth the mess.

Her lectures are fine and normally pretty easy to follow, but homework is 35% of your grade and graded for accuracy on paper. Also, she makes you complete it in "homework groups", which basically means you are responsible for other people not understanding the problems and it can severely impact your grade.

Prof. Smith has a passion for math that helped me stay engaged for every 75 minute lecture. She is a great teacher and explains things well in class/on piazza, however, the grading is quite difficult. The exams make up 78% of the course grade, and sometimes things can appear that were not covered much in class. Overall fun teacher but hard class.

Ive never had a class where questions were graded so harshly. The TAs hate the students and the class/exam focuses way too much on useless proofs, rather than actual problem solving. The hw was done in groups, but no one helps with it and someone always ends up doing all the work/hard problems. However, Smith was the best option available.

She was easy to understand at times but not most of the time. She is a tough grader and assumes we know stuff that we dont. Still seemed like the best professor at the time in this class but I would look for others.

The grade was made up of homework (22%), two midterms (25% each), and a final (28%). Homework was group homework and most people didn't help; homework is graded harshly for accuracy even though it's supposed to be practice. The midterms and final way more difficult than the homework, and Leslie focuses way too much on proofs. Would not take again.

Professor Smiths lectures are awesome. Shes great at teaching, and understands when something she says isnt understood by the class. She isnt afraid to laugh at her mistakes, and the hw is manageable, being due once a week. However, the grading criteria on the exams is very unclear, and the grading itself is very harsh. Be ready to work.

She is a tough grader for sure. Exams are much harder than hws or any practice problems. I worked super hard and got AB. Not recommend especially for people who expect to get an A or AB in this class.

This class was pretty brutal online and not really what I expected at all. It seems like she focuses much more on proofs and why questions than other 320 classes. This class was extremely stressful for me but there was a generous curve at the end so it wasnt all bad.

She's a tough teacher, but an amazing one as well. She really knows how to explain concepts to students and is always willing to clarify things if needed. By far one of the most helpful instructors I've had.

She provides lecture notes online, has very clear grading criteria, and explains things in a way that just makes sense. I believe she answers questions diligently, and it seemed as though she really cared that you understood the material. It's very important to pay attention in lecture, as she skips steps sometimes. But, she does explain why.

I took this course as the last math credit I needed for my major, and to say the least I was extremely disappointed by the lack of transparency and communication exhibited by this prof and the TAs. There was no clear guidance on hw, no help when confused, TAs were disorganized, and the online format wasn't adapted to.

Most of the class is struggling at pass this class and we have a few more weeks to go. TA is no help at all. Homeworks are penalized heavily, when they should be a learning opportunity. Seek office hours to clarify questions and help is vague at best. Dont recommend.

She knows exactly what she wants you to know and she knows how to explain it in many different ways, so if it didn't make sense the first time she'll try to explain it differently so that everyone understands. Her exams are very difficult

Excellent professor. Math 320 is a very difficult class, but her solid teaching makes it very doable if you're willing to put in the work. She's not an easy grader, and the exams will be very difficult. She clearly cares about whether or not students are getting the material.

Professor Smith was great, one of the best Professors I have had, especially in the Math Department.  Her lectures are very well organized and she puts all of her notes online for review. Her grading is fair and her tests are what one would expect; never any curveballs or anything. I highly recommend her
She's Amazing, just look at her CV. She's Brilliant, and an amazing professor. She will put the effort in to make sure you understand the material.

The course content is not that difficult, but she makes this class a nightmare. She is the type of professor who emphasizes derivations and theory rather than calculations. Her tests award very little partial credit. You will know the material well at the end of the course, but she makes this class impossible. Create your schedule around her.

She's very good at explaining the material. Everything is explained theoretically at first, just hang in there until she does examples and it will make more sense. The homework questions in the book are worded completely differently than the lectures. What you do in lecture is what will be on the test, not problems from the text book.

She's insanely smart and a good and interactive lecturer, but the derivations often put me to sleep. She emphasizes understanding over rote calculations. Study the practice exams and know the notes inside out to do well on exams. Curve was merciful in my case. Would recommend picking another prof, but it's not the end of the world if you have her.

Yes, she derives each equation used in class. However, her notes are clear, organized and she does ultimately give good examples and lays out clear steps to proceed with a problem. Her tests are tough and require you to remember everything you've ever learned in math and strong problem solving skills but overall they extremely fair.

Leslie is very intelligent and expects a lot out of her students. She teaches all the concepts using general terms and proofs and loves putting those on the test. The course material really isn't that difficult but the way she poses her questions requires you to think about what she's asking you to do.

She is very willing to help and is very smart; however, sometimes the lectures show that she is too smart. She goes very quickly and it is hard to keep up. I feel like i learned the basics in class and really needed the homework to do well.

She knows the topic that she is teaching very well, but sometimes will jump to conclusions, so it is very important to ASK QUESTIONS in class, which she is very open to. Overall, a fine professor who if you keep up and ask questions, will get you through the course more prepared than most professors. Difficult class, but worth it.
Terrible teacher, she expects half of the class to fail. Lectures are dense, and more of a researcher than a teacher.

The only reason some people may not give her good reviews is because all engineers are ready to be done with math by the time their last math class comes around.  Her lecturing skills are great, and her final curve is better than each individual exam's curves

Makes class much harder than it needs to be. Ridiculous curve (on one exam 3 kids out 90 or so got an A). Hearing from other students who have taken 320 with other professors, Smith teaches it much harder. Wouldn't recommend.

One of the best math teachers I've had.  She's really good at teaching but not always good about finishing a topic before putting it on an exam.  Grades exams with very little partial credit.  Tests you on proofs and concepts not just your ability to solve problems mechanically.
Great professor, teaches extremely well and with enthusiasm. grades exam extremely hard though

During lecture, she always gives great examples that are easy to follow. Her explanation on topics makes the book easier to read (if you like to read the chapter after you go to lecture). Most importantly though is that if you do her practice exams, you are guaranteed at least a B in any given exam

Interacts with students to really ensure that they understand the material.  Tests can be tricky, but the concepts on the tests represent material learned.  She cares about the learning of her students and presents great examples in class.  Even if you don't get an A, you will learn a great deal from this professor. Strongly Recommend this Prof!
Terrible professor.  Is not clear about what she wants on exams, makes about 10 mistakes per lecture which she annoying laughs at, and will not listen to student's concerns.  Avoid at all costs.

Prof. Smith always tries to connect with the students, strongly encouraging questions and reacting to any comments. Unfortunately this also means you better be somewhat attentive, as she will notice if you're dozing or whispering.
Lectures are pointless. Tests are almost exactly like the practice exams. Will say "Is it true?" at least 50 times per lecture. Actually cares that the class knows whats goin on.
Good Prof.  Tests are just like practice tests which is very helpful.  She goes pretty fast, but overall good professor
No Comments
Talks too much, needs to slow down and remember we're lazy college students
explains material very well.  homework fair and tests are relatively easy with no big suprises
No Comments
